verses.text: As the same apostle also, when he says, "In putting off the body of the flesh," certainly did not intend two things, as though flesh were one, and the body of the flesh another; but because body is the name of many things that have no flesh (for besides the flesh, there are many bodies celestial and bodies terrestrial), he expressed by the body of the flesh that body which is flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 16:16
verses.text: In like manner, therefore, by the spirit of the mind, that spirit which is mind.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 16:17
verses.text: Elsewhere, too, he has even more plainly called it an image, while enforcing the same thing in other words.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 16:18
verses.text: "Do you," he says, "putting off the old man with his deeds, put on the new man, which is renewed in the knowledge of God after the image of Him that created him".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 16:19
verses.text: Where the one passage reads, "Put ye on the new man, which is created after God," the other has, "Put ye on the new man, which is renewed after the image of Him that created him".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 16:20
verses.text: In the one place he says, "After God;" in the other, "After the image of Him that created him".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 16:21
verses.text: But instead of saying, as in the former passages "In righteousness and true holiness," he has put in the latter, "In the knowledge of God".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 16:22
verses.text: This renewal, then, and forming again of the mind, is wrought either after God, or after the image of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 16:23
verses.text: But it is said to be after God, in order that it may not be supposed to be after another creature; and to be after the image of God, in order that this renewing may be understood to take place in that wherein is the image of God, i-e: in the mind.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 16:24
verses.text: Just as we say, that he who has departed from the body a faithful and righteous man, is dead after the body, not after the spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 16:25
verses.text: For what do we mean by dead after the body, unless as to the body or in the body, and not dead as to the soul or in the soul? Or if we want to say he is handsome after the body, or strong after the body, not after the mind; what else is this, than that he is handsome or strong in body, not in mind? And the same is the case with numberless other instances.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 16:26
verses.text: Let us not therefore so understand the words, "After the image of Him that created him," as though it were a different image after which he is renewed, and not the very same which is itself renewed.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 17 —How the Image of God in the Mind is Renewed Until the Likeness of God is Perfected in It in Blessedness.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:2
verses.text: 23  Certainly this renewal does not take place in the single moment of conversion itself, as that renewal in baptism takes place in a single moment by the remission of all sins; for not one, be it ever so small, remains unremitted.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:3
verses.text: But as it is one thing to be free from fever, and another to grow strong again from the infirmity which the fever produced; and one thing again to pluck out of the body a weapon thrust into it, and another to heal the wound thereby made by a prosperous cure; so the first cure is to remove the cause of infirmity, and this is wrought by the forgiving of all sins; but the second cure is to heal the infirmity itself, and this takes place gradually by making progress in the renewal of that image: which two things are plainly shown in the Psalm, where we read, "Who forgiveth all thine iniquities," which takes place in baptism; and then follows, "and healeth all thine infirmities;" and this takes place by daily additions, while this image is being renewed.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:4
verses.text: And the apostle has spoken of this most expressly, saying, "And though our outward man perish, yet the inner man is renewed day by day".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:5
verses.text: And "it is renewed in the knowledge of God, i-e: in righteousness and true holiness," according to the testimonies of the apostle cited a little before.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:6
verses.text: He, then, who is day by day renewed by making progress in the knowledge of God, and in righteousness and true holiness, transfers his love from things temporal to things eternal, from things visible to things intelligible, from things carnal to things spiritual; and diligently perseveres in bridling and lessening his desire for the former, and in binding himself by love to the latter.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:7
verses.text: And he does this in proportion as he is helped by God.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:8
verses.text: For it is the sentence of God Himself, "Without me ye can do nothing".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:9
verses.text: And when the last day of life shall have found any one holding fast faith in the Mediator in such progress and growth as this, he will be welcomed by the holy angels, to be led to God, whom he has worshipped, and to be made perfect by Him; and so will receive in the end of the world an incorruptible body, in order not to punishment, but to glory.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:10
verses.text: For the likeness of God will then be perfected in this image, when the sight of God shall be perfected.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:11
verses.text: And of this the Apostle Paul speaks: "Now we see through a glass, in an enigma, but then face to face".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:12
verses.text: And again: "But we with open face, beholding as in a glass the glory of the Lord, are changed into the same image, from glory to glory, even as by the spirit of the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 17:13
verses.text: And this is what happens from day to day in those that make good progress.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 18 —Whether the Sentence of John is to Be Understood of Our Future Likeness with the Son of God in the Immortality Itself Also of the Body.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18:2
verses.text: 24  But the Apostle John says, "Beloved, now are we the sons of God; and it doth not yet appear what we shall be: but we know that, when He shall appear, we shall be like Him, for we shall see Him as He is".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18:3
verses.text: Hence it appears, that the full likeness of God is to take place in that image of God at that time when it shall receive the full sight of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18:4
verses.text: And yet this may also possibly seem to be said by the Apostle John of the immortality of the body.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18:5
verses.text: For we shall be like to God in this too, but only to the Son, because He only in the Trinity took a body, in which He died and rose again, and which He carried with Him to heaven above.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18:6
verses.text: For this, too, is called an image of the Son of God, in which we shall have, as He has, an immortal body, being conformed in this respect not to the image of the Father or of the Holy Spirit, but only of the Son, because of Him alone is it read and received by a sound faith, that "the Word was made flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18:7
verses.text: And for this reason the apostle says, "Whom He did foreknow, He also did predestinate to be conformed to the image of His Son, that He might be the first-born among many brethren".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18:8
verses.text: "The first-born" certainly "from the dead," according to the same apostle; by which death His flesh was sown in dishonor, and rose again in glory.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18:9
verses.text: According to this image of the Son, to which we are conformed in the body by immortality, we also do that of which the same apostle speaks, "As we have borne the image of the earthy, so shall we also bear the image of the heavenly;" to wit, that we who are mortal after Adam, may hold by a true faith, and a sure and certain hope, that we shall be immortal after Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18:10
verses.text: For so can we now bear the same image, not yet in sight, but in faith; not yet in fact, but in hope.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 18:11
verses.text: For the apostle, when he said this, was speaking of the resurrection of the body.

chapters.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:1
verses.text: Chapter 19 —John is Rather to Be Understood of Our Perfect Likeness with the Trinity in Life Eternal.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:2
verses.text: Wisdom is Perfected in Happiness.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:3
verses.text: 25  But in respect to that image indeed, of which it is said, "Let us make man after our image and likeness," we believe,—and, after the utmost search we have been able to make, understand,—that man was made after the image of the Trinity, because it is not said, After my, or After thy image.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:4
verses.text: And therefore that place too of the Apostle John must be understood rather according to this image, when he says, "We shall be like Him, for we shall see Him as He is;" because he spoke too of Him of whom he had said, "We are the sons of God".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:5
verses.text: And the immortality of the flesh will be perfected in that moment of the resurrection, of which the Apostle Paul says, "In the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump; and the dead shall be raised incorruptible, and we shall be changed".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:6
verses.text: For in that very twinkling of an eye, before the judgment, the spiritual body shall rise again in power, in incorruption, in glory, which is now sown a natural body in weakness, in corruption, in dishonor.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:7
verses.text: But the image which is renewed in the spirit of the mind in the knowledge of God, not outwardly, but inwardly, from day to day, shall be perfected by that sight itself; which then after the judgment shall be face to face, but now makes progress as through a glass in an enigma.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:8
verses.text: And we must understand it to be said on account of this perfection, that "we shall be like Him, for we shall see Him as He is".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:9
verses.text: For this gift will be given to us at that time, when it shall have been said, "Come, ye blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:10
verses.text: For then will the ungodly be taken away, so that he shall not see the glory of the Lord, when those on the left hand shall go into eternal punishment, while those on the right go into life eternal.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:11
verses.text: But "this is eternal life," as the Truth tells us; "to know Thee," He says, "the one true God, and Jesus Christ whom Thou hast sent".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:12
verses.text: 26  This contemplative wisdom, which I believe is properly called wisdom as distinct from knowledge in the sacred writings; but wisdom only of man, which yet man has not except from Him, by partaking of whom a rational and intellectual mind can be made truly wise;—this contemplative wisdom, I say, it is that Cicero commends, in the end of the dialogue Hortensius, when he says: "While, then, we consider these things night and day, and sharpen our understanding, which is the eye of the mind, taking care that it be not ever dulled, that is, while we live in philosophy; we, I say, in so doing, have great hope that, if, on the one hand, this sentiment and wisdom of ours is mortal and perishable, we shall still, when we have discharged our human offices, have a pleasant setting, and a not painful extinction, and as it were a rest from life: or if, on the other, as ancient philosophers thought,—and those, too, the greatest and far the most celebrated,—we have souls eternal and divine, then must we needs think, that the more these shall have always kept in their own proper course, i-e: in reason and in the desire of inquiry, and the less they shall have mixed and entangled themselves in the vices and errors of men, the more easy ascent and return they will have to heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:13
verses.text: And then he says, adding this short sentence, and finishing his discourse by repeating it: "Wherefore, to end my discourse at last, if we wish either for a tranquil extinction, after living in the pursuit of these subjects, or if to migrate without delay from this present home to another in no little measure better, we must bestow all our labor and care upon these pursuits".

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:14
verses.text: And here I marvel, that a man of such great ability should promise to men living in philosophy, which makes man blessed by contemplation of truth, "a pleasant setting after the discharge of human offices, if this our sentiment and wisdom is mortal and perishable;" as if that which we did not love, or rather which we fiercely hated, were then to die and come to nothing, so that its setting would be pleasant to us! But indeed he had not learned this from the philosophers, whom he extols with great praise; but this sentiment is redolent of that New Academy, wherein it pleased him to doubt of even the plainest things.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:15
verses.text: But from the philosophers that were greatest and far most celebrated, as he himself confesses, he had learned that souls are eternal.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:16
verses.text: For souls that are eternal are not unsuitably stirred up by the exhortation to be found in "their own proper course," when the end of this life shall have come, i-e: "in reason and in the desire of inquiry," and to mix and entangle themselves the less in the vices and errors of men, in order that they may have an easier return to God.

verses.name: Augustine: On the Trinity Book XIV 19:17
verses.text: But that course which consists in the love and investigation of truth does not suffice for the wretched, i-e: for all mortals who have only this kind of reason, and are without faith in the Mediator; as I have taken pains to prove, as much as I could, in former books of this work, especially in the fourth and thirteenth.
